He has a dog and a garden. He has books; and he digs in

He conveys to us chiefly what his eye sees, what his body
feels. He sees England (ngland) very clearly. He sees
its emptiness (emptines); ; he conveys the scarcity of people; the
predominance (predominace) of individuals. The is the dominant
figure (fogure). He can count her possessions (posses ons)-- a few ships; a few
great houses (hous s). He watches her progresses (progeresses). She is parliament (parliemtn),
press, society, law and order. But the man who sees this
the individual, is still cumbered and stiff. Writing is
still an art that requires great ceremony. What you make
with the pen is separate from what you say with the tongue.
Only a few years back words were written elaborately (elbaorately) in
lustrous ink upon valuable parchment; and the leaves,
bound together, were chained to the lectern and read,
by a few, in great physical discomfort,
on hard benches (neches) in the cold. Even now, when words are printed,
the great public is not the reader, or the paymaster.
Written words must please a single man in the first place,
must find its way into some noble room, where the nobles
and the gentry, have leisure (lisure) after hunting, after
seeing their estates, and controlling (contrlling) their servants,
to to pick up a book and read its history or sing its song.
For Words must tell stories; or they must sound to
the ear. For the nobles had their music; they played tunes
tunes to the words that the writers wrote.

It is the printing press that (th t) disturbs this company.
It is the printing press that makes the writer a many (nany) headed
many limbed. a mongrel with so many different parents (pearants)
that it requires a whole (hole) army of learned men, and a perpetual
provision of fine tasters to keep any order or distinction
between (etween) the different members. The presses of ,
, sucking in copy, and casting out legible books
that any one (nany one) could read was not a nice [feeder?] (fedder). Anything
that could be written could be printed. What Any morality,
any record, whatever men wished recorded (recored), it would deliver
as a book. Unlike the painter (pa nter) or the musician the writer
after the birth of the printing press is exposed to
innumerable inappropriate (inappropirate) and irrelevant (irelveant) solcitations (s licitaions).
Why not write the history (hist) of your parish? Or the life of a
Roman emperor? Why not take part in the government (governement) of your
country? Why not advise the soul of its perils (erils)? Why not become
pamphleteer (pampheleteer) historian (histroain) moralist, or playwright? The Press is
read to accept anything. And as the public (oublic) becomes less
servile (serivile), less martial less concerned to keep out the cold
and fight the enemy, as glass is fitted into windows
and pillows replace logs, the public adds its own invitation
to the writer. It is an inquisitive active (acti e) minded public;
it soon dissipates and takes hold of . It makes him
into an innumerable company (comany) of familiar spirits (sprits), one
preaching (pr aching) another delighting, another instructing (anotherinstructing). Only a few
still persist into making words into works of art.
